title: Vineland-St. Joseph football preview
text:
Vineland-St. Joseph football preview JOSH FRIEDMAN, @JFriedman57 3:06 p.m. EDT October 1, 2015 Vineland's Daivon Seymore stiff-arms Egg Harbor's Austin Smith during the Fighting Clan's first loss of the season last week. (Photo: Craig Matthews/Staff Photographer) 2 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Key Matchups Vineland OTs Sergio Avila-Polaha (6 feet, 3 inches, 245 pounds), Coby Chestnut (6-0, 230) and Alaattin Ardahan (6-2, 285) vs. St. Joseph OLBs Rha-sun Tapp (6-1, 200) and Chris Carey (6-2, 230). The Fighting Clan lost a key cog in their offensive line last week, as sophomore tackle Noah Sansalone suffered a right leg injury, which will sideline him for unknown amount of time. Chestnut and Ardahan are battling it out during practice this week to take over his position. Whoever wins, along with Avila-Polaha on the other side, will have his hands full against Tapp and Carey. The two have combined for four sacks this season — Vineland has allowed nine in three games. The Fighting Clan need to keep Tapp and Carey out of the backfield to come away with the victory. Vineland pass defense vs. St. Joseph QB Salaam Horne (5-11, 190). The Fighting Clan’s pass defense has allowed more than 150 yards in each of their last two games, and gave up a pair of touchdowns through the air in a loss to Egg Harbor last week. Horne is regarded as one of the top quarterbacks in in South Jersey. His numbers aren’t great this season — 8-for-27 for 140 yards and a touchdown. However, he could have a huge day against Vineland. Vineland LB Anthony Reyes (6-0, 220) vs. St. Joseph RB A’Laam Horne (5-11, 190). Horne has been the Wildcats’ bell cow this season, rushing for a team-best 374 yards and six scores. Vineland’s biggest strength this season has been its run defense. Starting linebacker DaQuan Cosby has been key part to that success, but a back injury has his status up in the air against St. Joseph. Reyes, a freshman, has played well next to Cosby this year, but if Cosby can’t go, he’ll have more on his plate. 
Keys to the Game Vineland can’t play scared. St. Joseph has been a New Jersey powerhouse for years, having won six straight state championships. While the Wildcats may win a seventh this season, they’re not as dominant as they have been. St. Joseph lost its season opener, the team's first setback since Sept. 20, 2013, and nearly fell to Millville last week, narrowly edging the Thunderbolts 13-7 in overtime. The Fighting Clan are still underdogs in this game, but they have a chance. They need to play aggressive and make St. Joseph sweat. Vineland needs to attack through the air. The Fighting Clan’s passing game hasn’t been very effective this season, producing just 84 yards in three games. However, St. Joseph allowed Millville quarterback Will Polhamus to throw for 181 last week while stuffing the Thunderbolts’ ground game for negative-8 yards. Vineland quarterback Isaih Pacheco needs to find a rhythm to give his team its best chance. Vineland has to play a clean game. During the Fighting Clan’s loss to Egg Harbor, they had three turnovers and committed six penalties for 55 yards. Two of those giveaways resulted in Eagles touchdowns and a crucial roughing-the-passer penalty allowed Egg Harbor to kick a field goal at the end of the first half. Vineland can’t give St. Joseph those kinds of opportunities. The Wildcats are too good not to take advantage. 
Prediction 
St. Joseph 20, Vineland 6 
— Josh Friedman 
Vineland (2-1) at St. Joseph (2-1) 
When: Saturday, 3 p.m. 
Where: Bill Bendig Memorial Field, Wood Street, Hammonton 
Coaches: St. Joseph: Paul Sacco (34th season, 290-57-5); Vineland: Dan Russo (3rd season, 7-16). 
On the air: Local cable Channel 9 will televise the game tape-delayed Saturday at 6 p.m. and Monday at 7 p.m. WMIZ-1270AM will broadcast the game live. 
All-time series: St. Joseph leads 1-0. 
Last meeting: St. Joseph 48, Vineland 0, 2014. The Wildcats dominated the first-ever meeting between these two programs, scoring touchdowns on their first six possessions en route to the victory. Rocco Ordille rushed for 102 yards and three touchdowns to lead St. Joseph while A’Laam Horne added a pair of scores on the ground. Vineland finished with just 32 yards of offense and two first downs. 
Key stats: 13 — Points scored by St. Joseph in its victory over Millville last Saturday. The Wildcats hadn’t scored that few points since a 14-6 loss to Hammonton in 2012. 3 — Vineland turnovers in its loss to Egg Harbor Township last Friday. The Fighting Clan had just two giveaways in their first two games combined. 542 — Combined rushing yards for St. Joseph’s A’Laam and Salaam Horne this season, nearly 75 percent of the team’s total (723). 2.16 — Average rushing yards per attempt allowed by Vineland this year. The Fighting Clan have yet to give up 100 yards on the ground in any game they’ve played. 354 — Passing yards given up by Vineland in the last two weeks. 9 — Sacks of Vineland quarterback Isaih Pacheco this season. 8 — First downs by the Fighting Clan against Egg Harbor. Vineland had 30 combined first downs in its opening two games, both victories. 633 — Rushing yards for the Fighting Clan this year. Vineland has only thrown for 84 yards. 
—Josh Friedman 2 CONNECT 4 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://vineland.dj/1KPyFb0 TOP VIDEOS
